mainheader: Plan Your Proposal: Guidance and Resources
staticText: Rapid Response Research (RAPID) - In addition to standard research proposals, NSF also has the Rapid Response Research (RAPID) proposal type. This type of proposal is used when there is a severe urgency with regard to availability of, or access to, data, facilities or specialized equipment, including quick-response research on natural or anthropogenic disasters and similar unanticipated events.

mainheader: Plan Your Proposal: Guidance and Resources
title: PAPPG Chapter II.E.1
staticText: additional information on RAPID proposals.

mainheader: Plan Your Proposal: Guidance and Resources
staticText: RAPID proposals are NOT for: (1) Projects appropriate for submission as regular NSF proposals. (2) Events that are unanticipated due to lack of awareness of timelines; or (3) Collection of only non-perishable data.

mainheader: Plan Your Proposal: Guidance and Resources
staticText: Prior communication with NSF Program Manager is required with email documentation confirming approval to submit a RAPID proposal - THIS IS THE FIRST STEP.

mainheader: Plan Your Proposal: Guidance and Resources
staticText: SUBMIT A 1-2 PAGE PRE-PROPOSAL (and/or any questions) to either to a PM managing the program where the research is aligned or to rapid-covid19@nsf.gov for a COVID-19 related proposal.

staticText: Once invited to submit a full RAPID proposal:

mainheader: Plan Your Proposal: Guidance and Resources
staticText: Title of the proposal must begin with the prefix "RAPID:"

mainheader: Plan Your Proposal: Guidance and Resources
staticText: EArly-concept Grants for Exploratory Research (EAGER) - The EAGER funding mechanism may be used to support exploratory work in its early stages on untested, but potentially transformative, research ideas or approaches. This work may be considered especially "high risk-high payoff" in the sense that it, for example, involves radically different approaches, applies new expertise, or engages novel disciplinary or interdisciplinary perspectives.

mainheader: Plan Your Proposal: Guidance and Resources
staticText: These exploratory proposals may also be submitted directly to an NSF program, but the EAGER mechanism should not be used for projects that are appropriate for submission as “regular” (i.e., non-EAGER) NSF proposals.

mainheader: Find information: News, Funding Opportunities, and Past Awards
title: Energy Frontier Research Center (EFRC) program
staticText: established in 2009 by the Office of Basic Energy Sciences to fund integrated, multi-investigator Centers focusing on energy-related "grand challenges" and use-inspired basic research needs.  The last EFRC competition was held in 2014 and currently supports 32 Centers across the nation, funded at a level of ~$2-4 M per year for 4 years.  The next EFRC competition has not yet been announced, but could be expected in 2018 when the current round of funding expires

mainheader: Find information: News, Funding Opportunities, and Past Awards
title: Office of Science (SC)
staticText: The Office of Science is further divided into several programs: ASCR, BES, BER, FES, HEP, NP, SBIR/STTR

mainheader: Find information: News, Funding Opportunities, and Past Awards
title: Office of Science Funding Opportunities

mainheader: Find information: News, Funding Opportunities, and Past Awards
title: Advanced Scientific Computing Research (ASCR)
staticText: ASCR supports research in applied mathematics, computer science, high-performance networks, computational partnerships (SciDAC) and educational programs.

mainheader: Find information: News, Funding Opportunities, and Past Awards
title: ASCR Funding Opportunities

mainheader: Find information: News, Funding Opportunities, and Past Awards
title: Basic Energy Services (BES)
staticText: BES supports a variety of research disciplines that seek to discover new materials and design new chemical processes.  BES also supports the Energy Frontier Research Center (EFRC) program.

mainheader: Find information: News, Funding Opportunities, and Past Awards
title: BES Funding Opportunities

mainheader: Find information: News, Funding Opportunities, and Past Awards
title: Biological and Environmental Research (BER)
staticText: BER supports research on atmospheric processes; terrestrial ecosystem processes; subsurface biogeochemical processes involved in nutrient cycling, radionuclide fate and transport, and water cycling; climate change and environmental modeling; and analysis of impacts and interdependencies of climatic change with energy production and use.

mainheader: Find information: News, Funding Opportunities, and Past Awards
title: BER Funding opportunities

mainheader: Find information: News, Funding Opportunities, and Past Awards
title: Fusion Energy Sciences (FES)
staticText: FES supports research in plasma physics with the goal of building the scientific foundation needed to develop a fusion energy source.

mainheader: Find information: News, Funding Opportunities, and Past Awards
title: FES Funding Opportunities

mainheader: Find information: News, Funding Opportunities, and Past Awards
title: High Energy Physics (HEP)
staticText: HEP supports theoretical and experimental research in both elementary particle physics and fundamental accelerator science and technology.

mainheader: Find information: News, Funding Opportunities, and Past Awards
title: HEP Funding Opportunities

mainheader: Find information: News, Funding Opportunities, and Past Awards
title: Nuclear Physics (NP)
staticText: NP supports research on heavy ion physics, medium energy nuclear physics, low energy nuclear physics, theoretical nuclear physics, accelerator physics, and isotope production.

mainheader: Find information: News, Funding Opportunities, and Past Awards
title: NP Funding Opportunities

mainheader: Find information: News, Funding Opportunities, and Past Awards
title: Advanced Research Projects Agency-Energy (ARPA-E)
staticText: ARPA-E supports high-potential, high-impact energy technologies that are too early for private-sector investment that have the potential to radically improve US economic prosperity, national security, and environmental well being.

mainheader: Find information: News, Funding Opportunities, and Past Awards
title: ARPA-E Funding Opportunities

mainheader: Find information: News, Funding Opportunities, and Past Awards
title: Office of Electricity Delivery & Energy Reliability (OE)
staticText: OE supports research on improving energy storage and delivery systems, as well as on cybersecurity  as it relates to the nation's electronic grid.  OE does not have a separate funding opportunities website, but any OE funding announcements would be posted on grants.gov.

mainheader: Find information: News, Funding Opportunities, and Past Awards
title: Office of Energy Efficiency & Renewable Energy (EERE)
staticText: EERE invests solutions for energy-saving homes, buildings, and manufacturing, sustainable transportation, and renewable electricity generation.  For example, EERE funds research on  energy efficiency in buildings, development of solar, wind, water, and geothermal energy technologies, fuel cells, bioenergy, and advanced vehicle technologies.

mainheader: Find information: News, Funding Opportunities, and Past Awards
title: EERE Funding Opportunities

mainheader: Find information: News, Funding Opportunities, and Past Awards
title: Office of Fossil Energy (FE)
staticText: FE supports research fossil energy research, such as clean coal technologies (carbon capture and storage) and methane production.  FE's funding opportunities are managed by the NETL.

mainheader: Find information: News, Funding Opportunities, and Past Awards
title: FE Funding Opportunities

mainheader: Find information: News, Funding Opportunities, and Past Awards
title: Office of Nuclear Energy (NE)
staticText: NE supports nuclear energy research and development, including improving the reliability, safety, longevity, and affordability of nuclear reactors, developing sustainable nuclear fuel cycles, and minimizing the risks of nuclear proliferation and terrorism.

mainheader: Find information: News, Funding Opportunities, and Past Awards
title: NE Funding Opportunities

mainheader: Find information: News, Funding Opportunities, and Past Awards
title: National Energy Technology Laboratory (NETL)
staticText: The NETL is a national laboratory owned and operated by DOE.  In addition to its own in-house research, which focuses largely on coal, natural gas, and oil technologies, NETL issues collaborative funding opportunities to partner with outside organizations, including universities.   NETL also commonly announces and manages funding opportunities on behalf of other DOE agencies, such as the Office of Fossil Energy (FE) and Office of Electricity Delivery and Energy Reliability (OE).  NETL also serves as DOE's focal point for all unsolicited proposals.

staticText: Art Works - To support the creation of art that meets the highest standards of excellence, public engagement with diverse and excellent art, lifelong learning in the arts, and the strengthening of communities through the arts. Matching grants generally range from $10,000 to $100,000. A minimum cost share/match equal to the grant amount is required.

mainheader: Plan Your Proposal: Guidance and Resources
title: Grant Program Description
staticText:
Research: Art Works - Awards to support research that investigates the value and/or impact of the arts, either as individual components of the U.S. arts ecology or as they interact with each other and/or with other domains of American life. Research: Art Works offers support for projects in two areas:
•	Track One: Value and Impact. These are matching grants ranging from $10,000-$30,000 for research projects that aim to examine the value and/or impact of the arts in any topic area(s) by using data and methods appropriate to the proposed research questions.
•	Track Two: Experimental and Quasi-Experimental Designs. These are matching grants ranging from $30,000-$100,000 for research projects that aim to test the causal or inferred-causal impact of the arts on individual or cohort outcomes by using experimental or quasi-experimental design methods appropriate to the proposed research questions.

staticText:
Our Town - Organizations may apply for creative placemaking projects that contribute to the livability of communities and through strategies that leverage arts, culture, and/or design toward achieving community goals. Our Town offers support for projects in two areas: 
•	Arts Engagement, Cultural Planning, and Design Projects (see below)
•	Projects that Build Knowledge About Creative Placemaking (see below)

mainheader: Draft Your Proposal: Section Instructions and Templates
staticText:
Typical NEH grant applications may include the following:
1.	Application Cover Sheet (1 page)
2.	Statement of Significance and Impact (1 page)
3.	Table of Contents (1 page)
4.	Project Narrative
o	Style - Individuals with a variety of professional backgrounds will read these applications and advise NEH on their merits. Project narratives should be written so that they can be understood by persons who may not have the same technical awareness as the applicant
o	Formatting - Follow the specific funding announcement guidelines. Use single-spaced, one-inch margins, 11pt font unless otherwise specified
o	Evaluation Criteria - See specific announcements for program-specific evaluation criteria to address
o	Work Plan - Describe the work plan in detail, including a schedule indicating what will be accomplished during each stage of the project
o	Staff - Identify project staff, duties and qualifications
o	Dissemination Plan - Explain how the results of the project will be disseminated in print and electronic forms
5.	 Budget Form - While all items should be justified by the narrative, further explanation may be included in brief budget notes. 
6.	 Appendices - Use appendices to provide:
o	Representative samples of the final or anticipated form of the work, prefaced with explanatory notes (if applicable); 
o	Brief Resumes (2 pages max each) for staff with major responsibilities for the project's implementation;
o	Job descriptions for any additional staff who will be hired specifically to work on the project;
o	Letters of Commitment from outside participants and cooperating institutions; and
o	Letters of Support (if allowed). Such letters will be more useful if they address the criteria for funding established for this category (see below).
7.	History of Grants - If the project has received previous support from any federal or nonfederal sources, including NEH, list on one page the sources, dates, and amounts of these funds. If the project has a long history of support, the sources and contributions may be grouped and summarized.
8.	Consultants and Advisory Board Members - List consultants to the project, members of the project's advisory board (if there is one), and authors of letters of support (if provided).
9.	List of Suggested Evaluators - Provide the names, addresses, telephone numbers, and e-mail addresses of up to eight potential evaluators, briefly indicating why each one would be appropriate. Do not list persons who would be excluded as reviewers because of federal rules governing conflict of interest.

title: USDA NIFA Topics
staticText: The National Institute of Food and Agriculture (NIFA) supports research, educational, and extension efforts in a wide range of scientific fields related to agricultural and behavioral sciences. To address contemporary agricultural challenges, we seek to catalyze transformative discoveries and enhance education and engagement.

mainheader: Find information: News, Funding Opportunities, and Past Awards
title: NIFA Challenge Areas
staticText: NIFA supports research, education, and extension in six national challenge areas. These challenge areas include food security, climate variability and change, water, bioenergy, childhood obesity, and food safety. This page provides details on each of these areas and their strategic goals.

staticText: Applying for a grant consists of three steps: (1) Search for a funding opportunity, (2) Determine whether you and your organization are eligible for the funding opportunity you’ve identified, (3) Apply for a grant.

mainheader: Plan Your Proposal: Guidance and Resources
title: NIFA Grants.gov Application Guide
staticText: Each of the three steps varies slightly based on the type of funding for which you apply. Differences in procedures for the primary funding mechanisms are noted here and in the and the specific RFA.

mainheader: Plan Your Proposal: Guidance and Resources
title: Appy to NIFA website
staticText: NIFA supports research, education, and extension activities through three primary funding mechanisms: competitive grants, capacity grants, and non-competitive grants.

mainheader: Plan Your Proposal: Guidance and Resources
title: FAQs on applying for a grant
staticText: this list of FAQs cover questions about the eligibility and gereneral submission

mainheader: Plan Your Proposal: Guidance and Resources
title: Grants Modernization and the new ezFedGrants System
staticText: NIFA is now using ezFedGrants, a new web-based system, to support this initiative. EzFedGrants is a grants and financial management system used by several USDA agencies.

mainheader: Plan Your Proposal: Guidance and Resources
title: USDA Grant Writing Webinar Series
staticText: Includes Grant Writing Tips/Essentials, Peer Review Process, and more.

mainheader: Plan Your Proposal: Guidance and Resources
title: Data Management Plans for NIFA-Funded Research, Education and Extension Projects
staticText: Includes requirements, recommendations, and FAQs.​

mainheader: Plan Your Proposal: Guidance and Resources
title: DMP Tool
staticText: Create, review, and share DMPs that meet institutional and funder requirements. The DMP Tool Blog and Webinar Series provide helpful guidance.

mainheader: Plan Your Proposal: Guidance and Resources
title: re3data.org
staticText: The Registry of Research Data Repositories is a tool for helping identify and locate online repositories of research data.

mainheader: Plan Your Proposal: Guidance and Resources
staticText: Regulations and Guidelines - As an administrator of U.S. government support, NIFA works in partnership with grantees to ensure responsible stewardship of federal funds. Our grantees and partners are required to comply with all relevant rules and regulations. The following resources are provided to NIFA’s partners and award recipient to support their adherence to federal regulations governing program performance.

mainheader: Plan Your Proposal: Guidance and Resources
title: Policy Guide
staticText: NIFA’s Federal Assistance Policy Guide describes agency policies and procedures.

mainheader: Plan Your Proposal: Guidance and Resources
title: Certifications and Representations
staticText: Certifications and representations provided through the NIFA application process.

mainheader: Plan Your Proposal: Guidance and Resources
title: Acknowledgment of USDA Support by NIFA
staticText: When acknowledging USDA support in accordance with 2 CFR Part 415, grantees must use the following acknowledgment for all projects or initiatives supported by NIFA.

mainheader: Plan Your Proposal: Guidance and Resources
title: Federal Regulations
staticText: The Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) lists all regulations published in the Federal Register.

mainheader: Plan Your Proposal: Guidance and Resources
title: FOIA
staticText: The Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) provides that any person has the right to request access to federal documents and information such as research data.

mainheader: Plan Your Proposal: Guidance and Resources
title: NEPA Policy and Guidance
staticText: The National Environmental Policy Act (NEPA) Policy and Guidance set the standard for identifying potential environmental impacts.

mainheader: Plan Your Proposal: Guidance and Resources
title: OGFM Issued Correspondence
staticText: The Office of Grants and Financial Management occasionally issues correspondence to applicants, grantees, and/or the general public for informational or clarification purposes.

mainheader: Plan Your Proposal: Guidance and Resources
title: Indirect Costs
staticText: Indirect costs are those expenses that support the shared goals of the project and grantee. Refer to the process for establishment of Indirect Cost Rates for more information.

mainheader: Plan Your Proposal: Guidance and Resources
title: Research Misconduct
staticText: NIFA requires that all its awardees adhere to the USDA Scientific Integrity Policy and the Federal Policy on Research Misconduct.

mainheader: Plan Your Proposal: Guidance and Resources
title: Terms and Conditions
staticText: Award terms and conditions provide specific guidance on program performance. Refer to the award document, Form NIFA-2009, to determine the applicable terms and conditions document.

mainheader: Draft Your Proposal: Section Instructions and Templates
title: USDA/NIFA Grants.gov Application Guide
staticText: The guide provided is meant to serve as an example. Refer to and follow the Grants.gov Application Guide provided in the application package on Grants.gov for the specific funding opportunity of interest.
